text:
This is fantastic!  My husband and son raved about it and couldn't wait for leftovers.  Delicious flavors and wonderfully moist.  For those of you who weren't that impressed, use teriyaki baste & glaze (not just a sauce or marinade) -- it's thicker and adds much more flavor than a marinade.  No need to marinade over night or hours before if you use this.  I used Kikoman baste & glaze and Hidden Valley ranch lite, with real bacon(low salt) crumbled.  I didn't fry the chicken - I just spooned on the baste & glaze to both sides of the chicken & then spooned on the ranch, with everything else following.  Great with an angel hair pasta with sauteed garlic, tomatoes, onions, and spices.

It was very good.  I like trying new things and this recipe hit the spot.  I'll be passing it on to my mom.  One note: I would add the chese until the last 10-15 mins of baking and next time, and I also like to use real bacon (4-5 strips) which I will cook while it is in the oven and when it is done, I add the cheese and bacon during the last 10-15 mins and it tastes fabulous!!

text:
My husband and I really liked this dish.  The only thing I did different was that I marinated the chicken in the teriyaki sauce for several hours. Then after browning the chicken, I mixed the remaining teriyaki sauce with the ranch and spooned the mixture over the chicken.  That eliminated the "gross" color I've read others complain about.  I think next time I will cover the dish with foil before baking to keep the cheese from drying out so much.  We eat baked chicken in more than 50% of our meals, and this was a really nice change from the ordinary.

Is 9:00 a.m. too early to eat the half of piece of this wonderful chicken leftover from last night? The only change I made was to dip the chicken into egg and then seasoned flour before sauteing. I also added a bit of teriyaki to the bottom of the dish before baking. I waited until the last 15 minutes of cooking time before I added my shredded cheddar. This dish was so good!

My entire family loved it!  I always use Lawry's brand teriyaki marinade instead of any other brand...not as salty, I guess because of the pineapple juice.  I followed this recipe to the letter except that I marinaded the chicken breast in teryaki sauce for about 20 minutes while the oven preheated. I served it with homemade garlic mashed potatoes, fresh broccoli, and garlic bread.  My husband and son had 2 helpings!

text:
This is by far the best chicken recipe I've tried on this site.  I didn't have some of the items, so I did a few substitutions and it turned out wonderful.  This is what I did:  I used real bacon and cooked it, saved the drippings and sauted the chicken in them.  I didn't have any ranch dressing, but I had ranch seasoning packet, so I combined whatever left I had of sour cream and plain yogurt with the ranch to make the dressing.  I also didn't have teriyaki sauce, but instead a marinating sauce, which isn't really "sauce", so I thickened the marinating sauce with corn starch and it was fine.  Other than that, I followed the recipe to the T and it came out perfect!  I only made two chicken breast and my sister who doesn't like cheese loved it.  Too bad I didn't make her any =/.  Oh, and I do agree that it is a bit salty (wasn't too bad for us), so you might want to use low sodium ingredients.

text:
I have to say this is a winner in my house!  I was skeptical like everyone w/ the flavor combo.  Made extremely minor changes.  I marinated the chicken breasts in the teriyaki sauce and poked holes in the chicken to have the marinade "seep" through for about 30 minutes.  I browned them in the skillet w/EVOO & blk pepper & red pepper flakes and then placed in the pan.  I used 1/2c ranch and 1/4c teriyaki and mixed together.  I poured liberally over the chicken.  Let bake half way through and pulled out, basted again w/sauce and added the cheese, bacon & onions.  Back into the oven.  About 5 minutes before removing, basted the tops w/sauce again and added a little more cheese & bacon.  Came out beautifully.  I should have made more sauce b/c it wasn't too salty by omiting the 1/4c of teriyaki.  Will make again and again.

This was pretty good.  I changed it a bit.  I scored the chicken and allowed it to marinate in the teriyaki for about an hour.  I used a mix for the ranch dressing, low fat chedder, turkey bacon and white onions.  My fiance did not like the ranch and I thought it tasted a bit salty.  Probably because I used the mix for the dressing.  Next time I'll leave off the ranch.  This was still very good and would make this again.

text:
Delicious.  I didn't bother sauteing first.  I pounded the chicken for extra tenderness, and then mixed the basting sauce and ranch dressing and spread generously on both sides.  Then baked for 30 minutes on 350.  Then for the last 10 minutes, I put on the cheese, bacon bits and green onions.  Everyone loved it.  And a much easier way to get the same results.

text:
WOW! This was absolutely awesome. My 2year old son, husband, and father-in-law loved this and that's rare in my house. I was so excited. This smelled wonderful as well. I did what others said to do...Used Kikkoman teriyaki baste & glaze (in the oriental section at the store), I mixed the ranch and teriyaki prior to brushing on the chicken. I used the jarred real bacon pieces and I put them and the cheese on 15 minutes before the chicken was done. I cut the chicken into smaller pieces and next time I will cut all of them into smaller pieces and make a little more sauce, maybe 2/3 cup of ranch and 2/3 cup of teriyaki sauce. WE ALL LOVED THIS STUFF=) THANKS SO MUCH FOR THE GREAT RECIPE=)

I wasn't going to rate this, thinking it has so many great reviews this won't make a difference, but I would hate for anyone else to try this out thinking it will be wonderful. First, the soy flavor is way too strong and does not mix with the other flavors. I consider myself a good judge of how something will turn out and I was very leary of this recipe, but assumed with all the great reviews it would be wonderful.  My husband wouldn't take a second bite (the man eats anything... but this dish) and I wasted chicken breasts. The bacon bits and soy together just do not work.

text:
This was good, and I think with a few modifications it could be GREAT.  I too had a problem with saltiness, and I didn't taste the ranch dressing as much as I'd hoped.  I think next time I will madinade the chicken in the teriyaki sauce and just add ranch on top.

I also didn't add the cheese, bacon bits, or green onions until only 10 minutes of cooking time was left.  It did not "bake off" or "look all goopy" like others had complained about when done that way.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken recieved an enthusiastic thumbs up from everyone in the family!! I made the following changes: 1. I used the Baked Teriyaki Chicken recipe from this site for delicious (and super fast and easy) sauce, 2. I used 12 bone-in thighs that I skinned and marinated for 4 hrs in a little of the teriyaki sauce, 3. I sauted real bacon and used the drippings to brown the chicken and onions, 4. I put a little teriyaki sauce in the bottom of the dish and also a little drizzled over the thighs. 5. Then I put the sauted onions overthe thighs. 6. I mixed the remaining teriyaki sauce and Ranch dressing and poured over the chicken. 7. Because I was also preparing Oven Fries (this site), I needed my oven at 450 degrees, so I covered the dish with foil and baked for 40 min, removing foil for the last 10 min.  The chicken was wonderful...there was no grease visible, color was certainly acceptable, the cheese had melted down into the chicken...the boys voted for more cheese!  Otherwise, we loved it, and I'd be proud to serve it to company, probably with rice to slurp up that delicious sauce...try the Baked Teriyaki Chicken for great teriyaki sauce...you'll never want to buy it again!!!

text:
Delicious. I contemplated making this recipe for the past two months because of the combination of ingredients. I'm so glad I finally prepared this for my family. My plan: double the recipe and serve at our Sunday dinner and have leftovers for Monday night. Well, it didn't work that way, my family enjoyed it so much Sunday night, I didn't have any leftovers for Monday night! I only served my kids a small portion because I didn't think they would like it but I was wrong. They kept going back for more. I knew my husband and I would like this after I brushed the basting sauce and ranch on the chicken. It smelled so good. This is what I did with this recipe: I pounded the chicken breasts thin, cut up real bacon & fried it till half cooked, added the cheese and bacon last 10 minutes of baking, made my ranch dressing - do not buy bottled dressing & I used Mr. Yoshida's original gourmet sauce. I omitted the onions becuase of my kids. The chicken breasts were great but I will prepare this recipe again using boneless, skinless chicken thighs. My husband kept giving me a thumbs up during our dinner and I know he overate. Please give this recipe a try, I'm really glad I did.

text:
I can't disagree with the masses.  This was fantastic.  I made it twice in one week it was so good.  Thanks for the great recipe!! (Added for the ones who didn't get this one right)  The Teriyaki has to be the BASTE & GLAZE (by Kikkoman, which is thick), not teriyaki sauce which is the consistency of water.  I tried it with both and I agree that the teriyaki sauce was not good. It has to be the BASTE & GLAZE, or a corn-starch thickened teriyaki sauce.  Also, I recommend you let it sit for about 5 minutes after pulling from the oven and cut around the cheese prior to plating.  This will help the ingredients remain on the chicken and not be left behind in the pan.

country:

text:
I made this for the first time for company (something I don't usually do!) and we ALL loved it! Made a few changes as I thought it might be a little dry: I marinated the chicken overnight in a full bottle of teriyaki marinade (used a full bottle, because I was cooking for 12 people), then browned the chicken in some olive oil. Dumped an entire LARGE bottle of Ranch dressing on top and baked it for 25 minutes; then added 1/2 lb.shredded sharp cheddar and a full bottle of real bacon pieces (not imitation bits) and chopped scallions. Cooked it for another 15; then let it sit in warm over for about 15 minutes or so as company was not quite ready to eat. Ingredients combined completely for a great sauce (it looked nothing like the picture), and what a sauce!! WOW! The flavors combine just perfectly. Would be great over rice or just a loaf of crusty bread to mop up the sauce. Can't wait to make this one again!! A friend who was there wants me to make it for his mother's 40th anniversary party!

The mix of this recipe's ingredients are unique and delicious (although on the salty side). I found 1/2 cup teriyaki and 1/2 c ranch along with the chicken juices, made about 2 cups of "sauce". We did not use that much sauce for 6 breasts, so I will use half amounts next time or use (it)in rice or pasta. I loved the quick and easy prep and using a bake-safe frypan(instead of a frypan AND a 9X13 bake dish), I only had to clean 1 big pan. Believe me, 500 people are not wrong. This is an excellent recipe!

text:
This was VERY GOOD! My boyfriend absolutely loved it and said it was the best chicken he has ever had.  I did agree with some of the other reviewers that it was a little salty, but I didn't think it was overbearing.  I'm making it again today and this time I'm going to pre-marinate the chicken in the teriyaki sauce and ranch with some garlic for about an hour.  I'm hoping this will make the chicken even more juicy and flavorful than the first time!  Also, make sure when you add the cheese that it's not until the last 15 minutes or so because it will get quite hard and somewhat crusty if it is in the oven the entire time.

text:
this was VERY good but with some changes-- First, you MUST use real bacon (I used 3 slices for 4 chicken breasts). Also, I only had teriyaki marinade not sauce so I marinaded the chicken for an hour and browned it in the same pan I cooked the bacon in (so I used the bacon fat instead of oil). I used sharp cheddar cheese and this dish was amazing! And the green onions are a MUST it gives it that great "creamy bacon and chives" flavor. Give this dish a try!!

text:
This is seriously delicious!  You wouldn't think all the flavors would go together, but they do!  I marinated the chicken in the teriyaki sauce for several hours, then browned the chicken with the marinade.  Placed in a dish, covered in ranch and baked until almost done.  Then I covered each piece of chicken with cheese, bacon bits and green onions.  I cooked until the cheese was melted and chicken was cooked all the way through.  Delicious!

I've made this twice now and LOVE it!  I made it the first time with light ranch and the second will reg. ranch and surprisingly I liked the light ranch better! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this today and it was delicious,  I fried real bacon (about 8 oz) and then browned the chicken in two tbls. of the bacon grease. I pounded the chicken so they cooked evenly.  As suggested I used the  teriyaki glaze instead of the sauce.  I used 3/4 tbls of glaze and ranch dressing for extra sauce. I mixed the glaze and ranch dressing together before pouring it on.  I added the cheese, onions, and crumbled bacon about 15 minutes before the end.  I served with a baked potato and broccoli.  Everyone loved it.  Thanks for this recipe.

However, I did marinate the chicken breasts in 1/3 cup of the teriaki sauce for three hours prior to cooking. I used real bacon, which I think only added to the great flavor. Very very moist and delicious.  I will make again!

text:
This was great.  A treat for the taste buds.  I had to make a few changes though.  Since I didn't have any teriyaki sauce I borrowed a recipe from "Baked Teriyaki Chicken" on this website.  I made sure it was nice and thick (which meant I didn't have to marinade it) and ended up mixing it with the ranch prior to putting it on the chicken.  It's all going to end up that way anyway, right?  I did not use any green onions, to my dismay, since my DH doesn't like them.  I ended up waiting until the last 15 minutes before adding the cheese.  It's definitely going to become a regular at my house.  I served it with rice and green beans...add a little extra sauce on that rice and YUMMY!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the most magnificent chicken recipes around!  The flavors blend together into a wonderful mixture of savory, juicy sauce over succulent chicken.  I made my own teriyaki marinade, the Easiest Teriyaki Marinade Ever on this site, and I halved the cinnamon amount in that and upped the soy sauce content.  I let the chicken breasts chill in the marinade for a couple of hours before completing the rest of the recipe.  I also made my own ranch dressing, Ranch Dressing II on this site, and used it instead of store-bought.  A wonderful outcome of flavors in a perfect meal.  I served it all over angel hair pasta slightly flavored with garlic butter and herbs, and I added more cheddar cheese than what this recipe calls for.  Like other reviewers suggest, I, too, recommend adding the bacon bits (use Real Bacon Bits, not the fake nasty stuff), green onions, and cheese during the last 10 minutes of cooking time.  You will not be disappointed by this one, folks.

text:
I was surprised how good this was.   I used thinly sliced chicken breasts and only browned them for about one minute on each side, and baked for about 20 minutes.  They were perfectly done.

As others suggested, make sure you use a teriyaki baste/marinade, and not regular teriyaki sauce.  The baste is thicker and I think adds more flavor. 

Served with some sauteed broccolini and small roasted potatoes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/65375.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! As many others, I did not brown the chicken prior to baking. I felt it would possibly toughen it and not allow the sauce to seep in. Because I did not brown the chicken, I baked it a few additional minutes -- about 40 mins total.

I added half the cheese, onions and bacon before baking, then the other half about 20 mins into baking. It came out perfectly, with just the right amount of browning of the cheese.

I crumbled about 8 pieces of the pre-cooked Hormel bacon that we always have on hand and made ranch dressing by combining 1/3 c. each mayo/milk + 1 TBS dry ranch mix.

As others have mentioned, be sure to use the teriyaki glaze/basting sauce, not the watery marinade. Thanks for a unique and very tasty recipe!

text:
SOOOO GOOD!!! I made a few adjustments based on my time and what ingredients I had. First of all, I used FROZEN Chicken Tenderloins. I guess I could have thawed them, but I didn't feel like it. I also skipped the browning of the chicken, because I didn't see it as a necessary step. I also did not use any green onion or parsley. Simply put, I placed my frozen chicken tenderloins in a glass baking dish. Basted them with KC Masterpiece Honey Teriyaki Marinade. Poured on Kens Steakhouse Ranch dressing. Put on some fully cooked pre-packaged bacon that I broke up with my fingers. Lastly, used Kraft Mexican Blend Shredded Cheese. I covered the dish with aluminum foil and "PRESTO"! 35 Minutes Later, I had the BEST chicken EVER!!! It was a huge hit and SOOOO EASY!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I wasn't sure about the flavors, but it worked. I didn't have teriyaki basting sauce and I find the store bought teriyaki way too salty. I combined teriyaki, soy sauce and honey and thickened it over the stove with cornstarch and water. When it was the right combo of sweet and salty I brushed in on the chicken. I didn't have shredded cheese so I put a small piece of cheddar on the chicken. I used real bacon, and probably more than 1.5 oz. But who can go wrong with bacon! I served over thin spaghetti. I think only a thin or angel hair pasta would work with this.

This was just an okay recipe for me, but my husband loved it!  He offered to make me another meal so that the leftovers could be reserved for him. text:
I have made this recipe as written twice and it was wonderful both times. Yesterday I knew I wasn't going to be home to cook it, so I tried it in the crock pot and was very happy with the results. I put about 10 frozen chicken tender pieces in the crock pot, along with the teriyaki glaze, the ranch dressing, the bacon pieces and the green onion. After 1 hour I stirred to combined. Then 30 minutes before serving I added the shredded cheese. All together it cooked for about 2 hours 45 minutes on high. I served it over rice and it was delicious! Both my 8 and 4 year olds loved it. I will be making this again!

country:
None
text:
How to make this less fat: You can get away making this dish with less fat but the flavor is still great.  I use real bacon but about one slice per serving.  I use just a sprinkling of soy sauce per breast and brush with low fat ranch and just sprinkle with shredded cheddar and the green onions.  Still a little fattening but not quite so bad but still totally delish!  Also I cut the breasts in half and pound to about 1/2 inch thick which speeds cooking time and makes the breasts really tender and streches the servings.  A favorite dish that really makes anynight special.

amazing combination of flavors & was so easy to put together.  this one is a keeper b/c i typically have these ingredients on hand. plus it's a different chicken dish than i'm usually making, so it's a nice change if you are bored of the same old chicken recipes. i pounded out 4 chicken breasts & was careful not to overcook them in the frying pan.  chicken was done sooner than 25 mins so keep an eye on the oven.  i also used real bacon instead of bacon bits & i think the flavor was probably far better than store bought bacon bits.  overall, delicious flavors & the chicken was kept moist by the ingredients on top.

I didn't have any ranch dressing, so I used lowfat blue cheese dressing, which I had on hand (there weren't a lot of blue cheese chunks in the dressing, so I thought it could work). I used my personal favorite teriyaki, Mr. Yoshida's. I'd never bought bacon bits before, and was happy to see there was a real bacon bits product available. I was tempted to salt and pepper the breasts for sauteeing, but I held back, due to reviews stating the recipe was too salty. This recipe was FABULOUS!  My husband was amazed (as was I)! I served with seasoned rice and a green veg on the side.

text:
I mixed the teriyaki and homemade ranch together and didn't saute the chicken first-just baked a little longer.  It sounds like people are using regular teriyaki sauce instead of teriyaki basting sauce - the two are different, regular teriyaki sauce is saltier.  Definitely use Teriyaki BASTING Sauce, because it's salty even this way.  Next time I won't put any salt in the ranch dressing.  May also leave off the cheese and bacon, could barely taste them, but the scallions definitely add a lot.

text:
I was skeptical whan I read this recipe - I wasn't sure how the combination of teriyaki and ranch would taste.  I'm glad I trusted the reviews and tried it.  My husband took one bite and said "It's a keeper!".  I didn't have thick teriyaki sauce (as other reviewers recommended), so I substituted thick Caribbean Jerk sauce.  I brushed it on the chicken, then baked it for 10 minutes before adding the ranch and bacon bits.  I bakeed it an additional 10 minutes, then covered it with a four cheese blend and baked it for 10 more minutes.  I will definitely make this again and again!

country:

text:
Ok, I had very high expectations for this one. I used 6 slices of bacon and made it on the George foreman grill. I then put seasoned the chicken and also put them on the grill to quickly brown on both sides. This method worked great. It followed the recipe as written and it looked great and even smelled good. When we ate it though, was not too happy with the taste of the teriyaki and ranch together. My kids liked it and it wasn't the worse thing I have made. But the combination of the sauces were not good. I would make again with a change. Next time no teriyaki sauce and just use the ranch. The chicken was moist and it was easy though. So maybe it is just a matter of taste.

text:
This turned out okay. The chicken was moist, which was its saving grace. I made my own teriyaki glaze and used regular Hidden Valley ranch dressing, topped with bacon bits and mozzarella cheese. Per some suggestions I covered the dish with foil while baking. The cheese and bacon bits slid off during cooking, which didn't leave a very nice presentation. The sauce had good flavor but the ranch dressing made for another unsavory look. Next time I will combine the teriyaki and ranch before pouring over the chicken, and then add the cheese and bacon bits (or real crumbled bacon) after they come out of the oven.

Display Name:
TC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome!! After reading a few reviews and adding my own twist, this came out great! Here is what I did:
First, I greased the bottom and sides of a 9x13 pan with coconut oil, then placed 7 small RAW chicken breast halves (could have fit 2 more) in the pan. I thoroughly mixed together the Teriyaki sauce and Ranch Dressing in a measuring cup and poured this over the chicken. Then I sprinkled dried chopped chives over all. I didn't have time this morning to cook bacon, (plus I don't like bacon) but I buy pre-sliced pepperoni and had some in the refrigerator, so I used my small 2 cup food processor and chopped up about 1/2 cup worth to make crumbly and sprinkled it over each piece of chicken, then topped with the cheddar cheese. I covered the pan with foil and baked it at 200 degrees (equivalent to a slow cooker on low) and baked for 6 hours. Very Very moist and tasty!! :)

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe! My husband loved it and so did I.  Some reviewers noted that this recipe was too salty, but they had to have been using the wrong ingredients like soy sauce instead of teriyaki because we had no problem with an overly salty flavor.  Cannot really describe the flavor of the chicken other than it was really good. I followed the directions and did not make any changes except that I did cover my baking dish with foil which I feel kept the chicken from drying out and the cheese from burning/crisping and I also cooked up bacon and crumbled for the bacon bits. I also agree with another reviewer about using Lawry's teriyaki marinade it was perfect, not too runny but not too thick.  I served this with fully loaded baked potatoes and it was awesome!  Highly recommend trying this recipe, it was delicious!

None
text:
After pulling out chicken breast for lunch I realized I didn't have anymore lemon pepper to make my usual. So I looked on here to find a quick and easy way to cook my chicken. The only thing I didn't have was green onions which I probably wouldn't have used anyway due to the fact I don't care for them.  This was a great easy way to make chicken quickly. I will definitely be make this again when the hubby is hm next time. The only thing I did differently was spread butter on bottom of my baking dish to prevent sticking and just because I'm a firm believer that everything is better with butter. This way I had a lil sauce to put on top of my chicken. Also I cut down the baking time to 20 mins due to the fact that I was only cooking 2 chicken breast and I didn't want it dry. I would recommend this friends and family anytime. Thanks for the recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
Shannon
isPro:

303

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Given the ingredients and cooking method, this recipe was pretty much what I expected...not fabulous, but fairly decent. I had to improvise a bit...didn't have the basting sauce, so I used 1/3 c teriyaki sauce, and an eyeballed amount of honey and minced garlic. I seasoned my thin-cut chicken breasts with pepper and garlic/onion powders. I browned the chicken as directed, but because the breasts were already the thin-sliced variety, I only had to bake 10-15 min at 350. Next time, I would skip the browning altogether. Baked on a parchment paper lined baking sheet (why scrub a baking dish, given the teriyaki glaze is likely to burn?) Didn't measure the cheese, ranch dressing, or bacon bits (used the Oscar Meyer real bits), but rather I used the desired amount of each on the chicken, and finished off with a few shakes of dried parsley to dress it up. Had to omit the green onion simply because I didn't have it. Husband devoured this...I thought it could use some tweaking, but I will make again with some changes. I'm excited to use this recipe as a stepping stone to put my own spin on it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a must in our house. I am a salt lover so I have no problems with salty food. I have made it several ways and this is the best I have come up with. Mix the teriyaki sauce half and half with ketchup. Fry the bacon and then brown the chicken in the bacon grease. Transfer to oven and brush with teriyaki mixture. Let cook 5 minutes and brush again at this time add the ranch. Cook 10 more minutes add the cheese and bacon for the last 5 minutes of cooking then sprinkle with green onions. Muah Perfect!

text:
This was delicious!  It was easy to make (my three-year-old son helped me with it), quick and full of flavor.  I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil, 4 chicken breasts instead of 6, for the ranch I used light sour cream mixed with a ranch seasoning packet to save on fat and calories and in place of the bacon bits, I browned up some turkey bacon and put that on top.  Both kids (3.5 & 1.5) ate it and thought it was good (that's a winner in my book!).  My husband said, that it's a keeper!  It reminded me of a twice baked potato, only instead of all the carbs you're getting a lean protein.  You could make it even more diet-friendly by using less teriyaki and reduced fat cheddar cheese. I will try that next time.  This recipe is a WINNER!

text:
I have made this dish three times and every time it is a hit with the family!!!  I read several reviews regarding the saltiness of the chicken, my guess is using the wrong teriyaki sauce.  Although it is not an "authentic" teriyaki sauce, I always use Yoshida sauce (available at Costco in the big jug)  and nothing I have cooked with this sauce has ever been too salty.  BTW, I followed directions loosely without changing ingredients, except the bacon bits, I used fresh.  Oh, and just squirt the ranch right from the bottle onto the chicken, why wash another spoon?!

text:
Very good! I took the advice of some other reviewers and this turned out sooo tasty for a low-carb diet! First I cooked the chicken until it was just brown on the outside, then threw it in a gallon ziplock bag with hoison sauce and soy sauce because I didn't have any teriyaki. Let it marinate for 20 minutes while the oven is preheating. I also used real bacon and didn't put the bacon or cheese on until the last 10 minutes of cooking. Very very tasty and will try it with teriyaki next time!

text:
This is delicious!  I made a few changes.  I mixed the teriyaki sauce and ranch together, and used more dressing, and marinated the chicken in it for about an hour.  I then put the chicken in a baking dish and poured the remaining mixture over it and baked for 35 minutes, adding the cheese and bacon the last 5 minutes.  I cut out the onion completely.  This turned out so incredibly moist and delicious, I've made it time and time again!

text:
Made this last night. Didn't have bacon bits. But the family still ate it up. I can hardly wait to try it with bacon in it. Thanks.
Update: We've made this several times as written and making a few tweaks like: no bacon, regular onions vice green onions, real bacon vice canned or bagged bacon, even different cheese. Bottom line, we like it every time. This has been a great start to many nights of enjoying chicken breasts. I still give the original recipe 5 stars as written. But don't be afraid to tweak it for taste or what you have on hand. One more thing, the Teriyaki sauce is something we always use and something we've always used.
Thanks for sharing.

Made this for supper last night just as written, except I grilled the chicken breast on a preheated gas grill for 5 minutes per side avoiding frying the chicken breast and adding fat to the recipe. Next time I may add some roasted garlic or even Jalapeno to some of the breast to add a little spice.

This recipe came into my email yesterday and it looked interesting and easy to make. I was a little skeptical with the combination of teriyaki sauce and ranch dressing. text:
This was fantastic!!  I marinated the chicken for a couple hours w/ my teriyaki sauce (I did not have the basting sauce)  Then I forgot to brown it.  I just dumped it into a pan, poured ranch over the top and let it bake.  After about 1/2 hour I topped w/ cheese and bacon bits and put it back in for 5-10mins.  I served with baked potatoes but I think it'd be great with rice!  My DD (whose 6) thinks I could put it all the the crockpot, even the potatoes and veggies!  She loved it!  ***UPdate**  I made it in the crockpot & it's just as good!  I marinated in the teriyaki for a couple hours.  Then put cut up potatoes then chicken then mixed calif veggies in crockpot.  (put ranch over the chix) Cooked on high for 4 hours then put on cheese and bacon bits for another 1/2 hour!

text:
This was absolutely wonderful.. I browned the chicken breast with chicken seasoning on the in bacon fat that was left over from cooking the bacon that goes on top. I added the ranch dressing to cover and baked for 10 mins then added  more ranch and cheese and baked another 20 mins. After the 30 mins total i added the crumbled up bacon pieces and spooned the stuff in the bottom of the pan on top and baked for 5 more mins. ( i used very thick chicken breast ) It was so juicy and wonderful! not salty at all.. My husband loved it and said it was one of the best recipes I have tried so far!  will definitely be making this more and often!! Thanks for sharing!

text:
Yummy stuff.  Guess I'm not the only one who was skeptical of teriyaki and ranch LOL, but it was surprisingly good.  And fairly filling for chicken.  Made as is except I usually cook in Pam instead of oil, and used real bacon.  I suspect half the teriyaki sauce is enough, and that's even considering I spooned some of the extra liquid over the top before eating - there was still leftovers.  I suspect this recipe isn't as difficult as I made it.  I usually just use soy sauce instead of buying a jar of teriyaki sauce, and at the last minute decided to dig up a recipe on here for it.  So I had to stop and make that, & it still just tasted much like soy sauce.  I don't like ranch on salads so never have ranch dressing around, so got the bright idea to buy the HV mix and just make part of it up.  So I had to stop and make that too.  (And it has fresh milk so unlike bottled kind, I have to now get it used up!)  And then cooked up real bacon.  If all I'd done is nuked a bit of bacon in the microwave and nothing else, I'm sure this would've been easy.  Hmm... my own fault.  But was mostly worth it.  And had leftovers that were almost as good heated up.

text:
For some unknown reason, it has taken me 6 years to try this top-rated recipe, and how sad I am for that lost time!!  My husband said this was one of the best chicken recipes I have made, and I agree!  I made this for 2, so I just eyeballed all measurements.  I marinated the chicken in the teriyaki sauce for 1 hour (vacuum sealed in a canister), then breaded the breasts with panko bread crumbs before sauteing.  I was out of ranch dressing, so made some with the seasoning packet (because of the salty comments, I subbed garlic and onion powders for some of the Ranch seasoning).  I used mild Cheddar and real bacon on top of the chicken, no green onions.  I though the final presentation was nice, I didn't get the "gross" color that others have mentioned.  Result was very moist and delicious.  Thanks so much for a new favorite chicken recipe!

city:

country:

text:
UPDATE: MADE THIS AGAIN (WITH SAME MODS AS LAST TIME), BUT INSTEAD OF BROWNING MY CHICKEN IN OIL, I FRIED UP 3 PIECES OF BACON (I HALVED EVERYTHING) AND RESERVED THE GREASE FOR THIS STEP. NOT ONLY DID I SAVE $'S I WOULD HAVE OTHERWISE SPENT ON BACON BITS, I ADDED A LOT OF EXTRA FLAVOR BY DOING SO. MAYBE THIS ISN'T THE HEALTHIEST OPTION, BUT IT SURE IS A TASTY ONE LOL! :) Pretty good.... My bf enjoyed this (a HUGE plus!), but I'm on the fence. I thought this was a tad bland. All I could taste were the seasonings (I sprinkled each breast with a touch of salt, pepper and garlic powder) and either teriyaki OR ranch (which didn't seem to blend well together...). Tip: use a NAME brand, high quality teriyaki GLAZE, NOT marinade (there IS a difference between the two). Marinade is THIN and not intended for basting! As many others have done, I too baked my (browned) chicken for 15 minutes, then topped with the "garnishes" and baked for an additional 15 minutes. Perfect! Served with fresh grilled corn on the cob and "loaded" herb mashed potatoes (with MORE melted cheese, bacon and green onion on top - Yum!). Thanks for sharing, VICKI! This was not bad at all. :-)

My favorite!  SUPER easy, SUPER yummy.  I have used frozen chicken breasts, but you have to almost double the cooking time to make sure it's cooked properly. This was very tasty! What I liked most about it was how easy and quick it was. My 1 and 7 yr old both loved it. My 7r old woke up and wanted more for breakfast! text:
This recipe is SO good! Just marinade the chicken in teriyaki for at least an hour before hand - the longer the better. DONT skip the ranch, I don't like ranch dressing but I used it anyway (just a thin layer on each chicken breast) and it REALLY adds to the recipe in a good way. Also, put the cheese and bacon on just for the last 5 minutes if you like it gooey, 10 minutes if you want it a little crisp. GREAT RECIPE!

I remember having something like this at a national chain restaurant, but I'm sure it was with bbq sauce not teriyaki.  So I made mine using some bold bbq sauce and it turned out SO good!  Better then the chain restaurant.  I also used real bacon, chopped up and cooked in the skillet, then used the bacon grease instead of vegetable oil to cook the chicken. Super tasty!!!

One of the best chicken recipes I've come across in a while. I marinaded boneless skinless chicken thighs in the teriaki sauce for about an hour then followed the recipe. I used sweet yellow onions instead of green onions and chopped up some leftover strips of bacon and mixed it with the sharpest cheddar cheese I could find for the topping. I would suggest adding the cheese and bacon during the last 5 minutes of baking. Served it with hot buttered rice. I'll be making this chicken often.

text:
I made this chicken for my fiancé and my sister two nights ago. My sister is extremely picky so I didn't tell her what was in it until she took a bite. She loved it. She ate her entire plate. My fiancé ate his entire plate as well. I actually had to get up and brown more chicken on the stove, add it to the remaining sauce in the casserole, add some more cheese, and crumble some more bacon and make this again because he wanted more! It DOES heat up very well too. I just got done having it for lunch today and it still tasted wonderful. I left off the chives and parsley, though due to my picky eaters, but it still tasted absolutely delicious. I, like just about everybody else, put extra teriyaki sauce on the bottom of the dish (I used Kikkoman teriyaki baste and glaze), mixed the ranch into the teriyaki rather than just pouring it on top, used more Cheddar than the recipe called for, crumbled up real bacon, and added the cheese and bacon during the last 15 minutes of cooking only. It felt like we were eating at a restaurant!

text:
I made this only because of all the great reviews. The flavors seemed like they would clash and I had little hopes for this one. I was so wrong - it was really delicious. I do not think anyone would know what is in it unless you tell them. Makes for a nice unique yet "safe" meal (ie pleasing to all types of people with all types of palates). I did make my own ranch sauce of galic, mayo, sour cream and herbs including fresh chives. For a makeshift teriyaki sauce I used soy sauce, brown sugar, maraschino cherry juice and a bit of dried mustard (hey it was what I had on hand and it turned out to be a great sauce)

Like many others I was a bit skeptical mixing these different flavors but was quite pleased with the result. This was a very quick and easy dinner and I had everything on hand except the green onions, so I sauteed yellow onions in the bacon drippings as called for in the Anniversary Chicken II recipe. The ranch dressing I had was with jalapeno so ours was a little spicy but very good. My husband loved it and suggested it for a dinner party. Seems to be one of those you can make ahead, refrigerate and maybe just allow a little more baking time.

I made a couple of changes.  First I marinated the chicken breasts in my own teriyaki marinade with low salt soy sauce. My only suggestion is to ensure you use low sodium teriyaki sauce in the dish - I did not and found it a little salty. My own fault I guess...

text:
I thought this recipe was actually very good! from the other reviews I see people said it was salty, but mine turned out with a wonderful taste! I put the chicken in a 9x13 pan and poured terriyaki sauce on it and baked it for about 15 minutes in the oven. Then I brushed the ranch dressing on it and topped with the rest of the ingredients. It was great. Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
This was great!!!!  My husband, who is a very picky eater, loved this and wanted me to make it again.  I was skeptical at first, but it was well worth the risk of trying a new recipe.  I took the advice of some other reviews, and I marinated the chicken in the teriyaki sauce for about 30 minutes and then browned.  I sauteed mushrooms in the left over grease/teriyaki sauce, and I added the mushrooms, cheese, and bacon about 10 minutes before removing from the oven.  Yummy!!!

text:
I must admit that I was very sceptical.  I have often been disappointed by recipes that have hundreds of great reviews.  However, this chicken had a very good flavor and was certainly 'dressed up' enough to serve to guests.  I used no oil (just a little water in the pan), much less cheese and real bacon (crumbled...I just can't do those 'bit' things).  I would make this again.  It was certainly easy and could be multiplied for a crowd.

text:
I made this with salmon instead of chicken, and it may be the best fish I have made. The 2nd time, I modified the procedure a bit. I used double the amts of teriyaki and ranch, mixed them together, and reduced it by half on the stove. This gives a thicker sauce which adheres better. Then I mixed the sauce with the cheese, bacon bits, and shallot (instead of green onion). I applied to the salmon and baked until ready (I didn't bother to sear the salmon on the stove first).Mmmmm

text:
Oh how yummy!!  The only thing I found wrong was that it called for WAY too much of the teriyaki, ranch, etc.  There's no way I could've used it all!  What I did was brush the teriyaki over the chicken, then top with 1 or 2 tbsp of ranch dressing per breast, then sprinkled the cheese and bacon (used real bacon bits - yum).  Don't care for the green onion.  I also had sprinkled a bit of seasoning salt over the chicken while it browned.  SOOOOOOOOOOO yummy!!

text:
It was terrific! Didn't have teriyaki glaze sauce so mixed teriyaki marinade in with the ranch dressing and poured over browned chicken.  Didn't have green onions so used part of a vidalia onion, chopped into small pieces.  Used crumbled, cooked bacon.  A bit salty, probably from the teriyaki marinade, but very good. Will make again.  -- Made again using basting sauce.  Though it is good, albeit salty, with teriyaki sauce, the basting sauce is important for a truly great dish.

Display Name:
Steph D

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1525722.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was a hit at our table.  I used the recipe as a guide with some of the other tips in the reviews. I marinated the chicken for about 2 hours in honey mustard (instead of regular yellow mustard) and honey...because we like sweet things.  Then I baked the chicken from the start at 400 degrees.  I also cooked my bacon before crumbling it and adding it to the chicken this kept the bacon crisp and not soggy.  Once the chicken was just about done, I added mozzarella cheese then the bacon crumbles and topped it with double cheddar cheese.  This helped the bacon stay on the chicken.  I drizzled a little bit of the leftover marinade for extra boost of flavor.  Then continued to bake...or melt the cheese.  Kids loved it...but who doesn't love bacon!?!?

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined a few other reviewers' suggestions and made substitutions according to what I had around the kitchen. After searing boneless thighs in butter I put them in a crockpot. I had no teriyaki glaze on hand so made my own out of duck sauce, soy sauce and minced garlic a few hours ahead and let it sit to blend. I coated the browned chicken with the glaze in a crockpot on high for a couple of hours, then added crumbled bacon and onions I browned in the bacon drippings.About an hour later I added the ranch dressing and mixed everything, then topped with white cheddar and let that melt for another hour or so. Served over a mix or wild and arborio rice, we LOVED it! Only 4/5 stars bc there was no single WOW flavor, maybe my substitutions made the difference. I'll make this again and play around with other seasonings we like.

I had decided to try this recipe as it had so many good reviews. I had read the negative reviews as well, stating the combination was a bit strange or was too salty and many did not enjoy it. Needless to say, I was nervous as to how this would taste. It came out pretty good though! I didn't find the flavor overpowering. The only issue I had was the cheese and ranch seemed to melt away. I will definitely make this recipe again! My husband and roomie enjoyed it and I did too! It isn't the best chicken recipe out there but I really enjoyed making it and eating it!

To the reviewer who said the cooking time made for dry chicken...with any recipe you may need to adjust the cooking time, as all ovens/stoves are different, and the temperatures might be off. text:
This was one of those let me make it, not tell them what's in it, and see what happens. LMAO. Hubby and the kids fought over the sauce, and boom, all the chicken breast was GONE. I did read other reviews. Yes, I covered the chicken in first baking it, then uncovered after adding the toppings. I did not sautee the chicken. I did mix the teriyaki and ranch dressing, adding a bit of garlic (we love garlic). I sauteed shallots (no scallions) and diced ham (no bacon). I am glad I made 1 1/2 times the basic sauce.

text:
Overall, not bad. Had to do a few things different. I did not use the recommended Teriyaki sauce. I replaced it with Pepper Palace's Bourbon Glaze sauce. It's not in stores but you can purchase it online. I sprayed cooking spray in the pan and placed the glaze on the bottom as well as the top of the chicken and then followed the recipe from there! We like lots of flavor to our chicken so I added avocado tomatillo salsa to spice it up. I think the chicken was too thick...Maybe if it were thinner I would not have had to add any flavor.

text:
Wow - I was surprised at how good this was! OK, I did not follow the recipe to a T. First off, I did not brown the chicken first (I'm lazy). Second, I did not layer the ingredients; I just mixed everything together (again, blame the laziness). Third, I did not have any cheddar cheese, but I did have some cottage cheese that I wanted to use up, so subbed that in. But REALLY, it's the mix of ranch and teriyaki that make this dish! I never would have put those 2 together, and it was a delightful surprise.

text:
I tweaked a few things based on other reviews. I had two really large chicken breasts and was just cooking for two of us. Did not have to change any portions. I browned the chicken, then put the teriyaki on top and placed in oven at 350 for 15 minutes. Then, I took them out and added the cheese, green onions, ranch, then a bit more cheese. Back in oven for 15 min. That's it. Super easy, chicken was very moist, and it was delicious! Served with wild rice. Can't wait to make it again!

This is pretty good, as my husband who doesn't like chicken said he liked it. For me, the tastier parts were when I got a bite with the dressing and all the other stuff; that was quite yummy. I will definitely make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
"Phenomenal" is what my boyfriend said. I marinated the chicken in Kikkoman Teriyaki sauce & marinade for a few hours. Then I mixed 1/2 cup Ranch dressing & 1/4 cup Teriyaki sauce together & basted chicken with it in baking dish. Did NOT brown prior to putting in the oven, but pretty much followed remaining cook time. Ended up turning & basting again after about 10 min, then added cheese/bacon/green onions for the last 5-10 & drizzled a little more sauce on top. SOOOO GOOD! Not too salty for us. Served with red mashed potatoes & baked zucchini chips from this site... we ended up using the sauce on everything because it was too yummy. Will definitely add to regular rotation!

text:
5 stars for being very simple to make & something different to try!  The changes I made were marinating in the teriyaki, chopping up 'ready cooked bacon' instead of bacon bits, using ranch yogurt dressing to cut fat & calories, and covering with foil for 25 minutes then without foil for an additional 6 or so minutes.  The yogurt dressing did make it a little harder for the toppings to stay on the chicken but still was workable.

country:
None
text:
READ THIS! Fantastic recipe...but here's an IMPORTANT piece of advice: Make sure you don't over cook the chicken as it dries out when over cooked and you'll end up with a large lump of hard-to-eat dried up white meat. Use a meat thermometer and cook until 165 degrees.  Or pound the breasts with a meat mallet until thinner then bake - this requires less time to cook! (ps: When in a rush I have skipped the pre-browning). If you don't have a meat thermometer GET ONE! A good one isn't even expensive and you'll wonder what you did with out it! Electronic is my fave - mine only cost $25).
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-07-11T13:58:09.583

text:
My husband and 3 kids (ages 1, 3, 6) all loved it!!  Everyone was pretty much licking the sauce off their plates, it was that good.
I used real bacon, and then browned the chicken in the bacon grease.  I stirred the teriyaki sauce (just had the kikioman marinade so I added a little cornstarch) and the ranch dressing together then poured it over the chicken.  After reading the other reviews, I added the cheese, bacon and onions for the last 5 minutes.  Only cooked for 25 minutes total.  Perfect!

text:
Well...my boyfriend and I made this and it turned out great, but we didn't quite follow the directions...oops!!  I had part of the recipe written down and knew what else had to be done, but when he was trying to help, it got all messed up in miscommunication.  We ended up marinading the chicken in the oil/sauce/ranch mixture and then baking it...tasted great and chicken was very moist!  We then topped it with green onions, mushrooms, and cheese and finished that in the last 10 minutes in the oven.  Served it with garlic mashed potatoes and it was delicious!  We would definitely make this recipe again...following the directions or ours :)  He doesn't even care for ranch and loved it so I'd say this one is a keeper!

Very good. Family liked it as well. The only changes I made were to marinade in teriyaki sauce for about 20 minutes prior to lightly browning. Browned in canola oil. Put small amount of teriyaki sauce on bottom of dish prior to placing chicken on top. Baked, covered with foil for 15 minutes and then put cheese, bacon, onion over top. Baked 7 min. covered, uncovered for about 10 minutes.

country:
None
text:
This is one of my favorite go-to chicken dishes.  I have modified it a little to make it quicker and easier, and it still turns out great.  I do not fry the chicken, I just pour the ranch and teriyaki basting sauce right over the top of raw chicken tenders (better size for the kids), roll it around to cover and then put it in the pan.  I then sprinkle on the shredded cheddar cheese and Hormel Real Crumbled Bacon.  Cook for 30 minutes and yum!!!

text:
I think this is in-between a three and a four.  The flavors were good, but I feel like the cooking the chicken in the oven step really cooked out some of the flavor.  I would suggest cooking your chicken until almost completely done on the stove top, then just melting the cheese in the oven.  I think the flavors work very well together, it is just the flavor is too light when you cook it the way it is stated, and I use a very strong Teriyaki glaze and it still didn't stay on.

4131135
Display Name:
Lippy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/387455.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this chicken! It is VERY savory and flavorful. I thought that ranch and terriyaki would be odd together, but it's delicious! I don't normally have seconds, but this chicken is so juicy and lip smackin good that I can't help but go back for more. The recipe unchanged is very good, but I've made it several more times using a few minor changes. I season the breasts with pepper and a tiny amount of salt and saute them in butter for only 2 minutes each side. I use my own terriyaki using low sodium soy (the Japanese Teriyaki Sauce recipe on this site) and made the ranch from a Hidden Valley packet. I also use 6 to 8 slices of real bacon, cooked, and I chop a medium brown onion and caramelize it (in butter and some salt) to top the chicken along with the green onion and bacon. Yum, yum, yum! I can't wait to have it again! Thank you for this recipe :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished eating this meal.  Wow!  Delicious! Because of what we had on hand, I used a bottled honey-mustard marinade and used the real bacon. We don't like to bake chicken in the oven because even in recipes that say, "It's SO moist," it usually tastes dry to us.  So I cubed the breasts and simply kept sauteing them until they were cooked.  I had already put the sauce together and simmered it in a pan on the stove for about 15 minutes. Put noodles in serving bowl, added the chicken on top, put the sauce over that, and added the bacon and cheese last.  Wonderful.  I'm anxious to try it again with the teriyaki basting sauce.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Really loved this dish.My chicken came out perfect.Better than I could ever had hoped for.Chicken is a dish that gets boring sometimes so it was nice to surprise my families taste buds with this little gem.I did make substitutions by using real crispy bacon rather than bacon bits.Then I sprinkled a little salt & pepper on the raw chicken breast halves,dipped it in some egg wash (1 raw egg mixed with 2tbsp of milk),after that I dredged it through a mixture of 1c of flour & 1/8c of corn starch,I used the same oil that came off my crispy bacon to brown my chicken breast rather than vegetable oil.When it came to toppings I didn't have any Teriyaki sauce so I followed an online recipe to make my own. This teriyaki sauce came out amazing even though I didn't have any ginger for it.I brushed on 1/2c teriyaki sauce spooned on the ranch & sprinked on the chopped green onions, baked for 25 minutes like that then pulled it out & sprinkled lots of shredded velveeta cheese over it with my broken up bacon bits.Then heated for another 10 min coverd. My picky 3yr old eat every bite & my husband raved. A+

text:
I am giving this recipe 4 stars, but will say it may very well deserve 5.  I made this last night and it was a hit. Only one small piece of chicken was left over.  I only made one change to the recipe. I had no bacon bits, so I took about 8 slices of bacon, diced it up and fried it to just about crisp. The rest of the recipe left as is.  I mixed the Teriyaki and Ranch together before spreading it on the chicken, and upon tasting it I was worried. It tasted as though the tastes did not blend well together. But I forged ahead and brushed it on the chicken and followed the recipe from there. My family loved it, and before I could say I was concerned about the sauce my husband said "This sauce is great!"  I will say the sauce did have a better taste after it had been cooked then it did prior, but I still want to try this recipe again without the Teriyaki and just the Ranch, Bacon and Cheddar.  So I gave it 4 stars. There are 5 of us in the family and 4 loved it, and I liked it. I do recommend using the real bacon though.  I don't think I will ever use the bacon bits.

text:
My boyfriend told me I get an A+ for the night.  Even hours after dinner, he was still talking about how much he liked it.  This is what I did differently from the original recipe:  I marinaded the chicken in the teriyaki sauce for about 30 minutes, skipped the browning, placed the chicken in the pan and coated them with the ranch, i added the onions and put it in the oven.  While it was in the oven, I fried up 5 slices of real bacon per other suggestions.  Since I didn't brown the chicken first, I left it in for about 45 minutes.  10 minutes before it was done I added the bacon and cheese (with a tad bit more than what the recipe called for).  It was FANTASTIC!  Will definitely be making again.

This chicken was AWESOME!!!  I browned the chicken in olive oil, rather than vegetable oil, adding some black pepper and garlic to both sides of the chicken while cooking. THIS CHICKEN IS INCREDIBLE!!  I made it in the crock pot, so easy! Just covered the bottom of the crock with teriyaki sauce, added chicken breasts and cooked on low for 6 hours, turning chicken over a couple of times.  I spooned on ranch dressing, added cheese and real bacon bits and then cooked 30 minutes more.  Moist and delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was amazingly easy and quick to make, while still tasting like it would have taken much more effort and time. Thank you! I had chicken breast (bone in) marinating in the refrigerator from the day prior, in teriyaki pineapple marinade, planning on grilling. I think that this helped with the salt issue others mentioned, because it was a thicker cut of meat. But, since the weather was not appropriate for a cook out, looked for another recipe, found this one. In addition to bacon and cheese, I sauteed some mushroom pieces in the frying pan with the remaining teriyaki sauce left behind, after browning the chicken. I put the mushrooms a top the bacon pieces before baking in the oven. As for what I served it with, I boiled spiral pasta until al dente (with two chicken boullion cubes in the water, instead o f salt). After removing the cooked chicken from the pan, I.Served the chicken atop the pasta, sprinkled sunflower seeds on it, and with a side salad w/ asian dressing...DELISH.

I CAN FIND NO COMPLAINTS. Excellent dish. Tastes great! Just cover with aluminum foil while baking and the cheese won't burn. For all the people complaining about the color...I've made this twice now and the second time I didn't smother it in the teriyaki and ranch...just brushed it on. Tastes the same and cuts back on the saltiness. Made mashed potatoes on side and used bacon bits, cheese and green onions in mashed potatoes. I've been getting weekly requests for this meal.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, what a great new way to fix chicken!  I thought the combination of teriyaki and ranch sounded disgusting but was pleasantly surprised at how well it mixed with the cheese, bacon and onions.  I cut the chicken breasts in bite-size chunks before browning in oil and then drained them on a paper towel.  Next, I mixed the ranch and teriyaki baste together and then dunked each piece of chicken in the mixture before placing in the 9x13 pan.  I spooned the remaining mixture over the chicken and baked for 10 minutes.  I used real crumbled bacon and mixed it with the cheese and onions after the bacon had cooled.  Topped the chicken with this and baked for 10-15 minutes more.  Served over brown rice mixed with shredded carrots and broccoli florets.  The only thing I'll do differently next time is make more sauce to go over the rice and maybe grill the chicken.  Delicious!

FABULOUS! This is rediculously easy to make and quick quick quick! Next time I will probably double the teriyaki and ranch on top of chicken. text:
This one was a mixed bag for us: 3 stars from my husband, and 1 1/2 stars from my 9yr old and myself - split down the middle, I gave this 2 stars.
I was hesitant to try this recipe because of the peculiar ingredients, however based on the rave reviews I gave it a shot.
I made the recipe exactly as is, using real bacon bits (my preference)and Soy Vay Very Very Teriyaki.  Part of the problem may have been the type of teriyaki I used, because this recipe came out almost too sweet.  It's the only teriyaki sauce I ever use, so I was surprised it came out that way. (I've marinated chicken with it in the past, and never had a problem)
My husband had 2 helpings and said he would eat it again, but my daughter and I only got through half of it before turning our plates in.  Our initial response was that we liked it, but the flavors became too much and it kind of got to us both.
My teenager wasn't home, so he'll get the leftovers.  
I probably won't make this again.

text:
I loved this and so did my family. I changed it a little, but I will try it this way eventually. I sprinkled Montreal seasoning on the chicken (saved time by not browning first, just baked for 50 min. @ 375 degrees) then spread the ranch dressing on (omitted teriyaki) and topped with bacon and red onion (didn't have green) added 3 cheese italian blend 10 mins before done. Super moist and super good! Will definitely be making again!

text:
Mine turned out really salty. I think it was the kind of teriyaki sauce I picked. Pick one with a pineapple or honey flavor in it. I also used peppered bacon I cooked myself instead of bacon bits, which added a little kick to it. Add the bacon and cheese during the last 15 min. of cook time like someone else suggested. Works great and keeps cheese and bacon from burning. I had this with a side of pears. The sweet of the pears went well with the salty of the chicken.

I used real bacon and followed the suggestion made by others and added the cheese, bacon and green onions after 15 minutes of baking. Thank you, Vicky, for putting smiles in all our faces and for sharing this great recipe!

outstanding recipe!!! changes I made: I fried up some peppered thick cut bacon and browned the chicken in the residue of the bacon grease. I added a thin layer of teriyaki sauce to the 9x13 pan  and I added my teriyaki to the ranch dressing and spooned it on. I added the bacon and cheese in the last 15 mins of baking. served with scalloped potatoes :) YUMMM!! it's a keeper!

Thank you so much for this wonderful recipe.  I think this would be good on butterfly pork chops too.

text:
I really like this recipe. It is a very rich chicken dish with all that cheese, so make sure you have some light rice on the side not to overdo the whole dinner. All in all the taste was very good but I overcooked it a little since my chicken breasts were on a small side and even 25 minutes made them dry. As previous reviews say - add the cheese in the last 10-15 minutes and try using fresh bacon instead of bacon bits. My bacon bits were very salty.

text:
I made this recipe for my family and everyone LOVED it! Like the others suggested, I held off on the cheese and bacon until the last 10 minutes, and it was nice and gooey. And I used real bacon istead of bacon bits. I also added a bit extra teriyaki sauce to the bottom of the pan, and then brushed the chicken with the amount the recipe calls for. The chicken stayed SUPER moist, and everyone commented on how flavorful it was. Very easy to make, and the boys were taking pieces of crusty bread and wiping the pan with them, making sure they got every last drop of the leftover sauce and cheese. This will definetly be a recipe I make over and over!

It seems like everyone is right about this recipe.  It's to DIE for.  I lightly breaded the chicken as some suggested (just dipped in egg and flour) and then continued with the recipe as written.  I think next time I will put on the cheese 10-15 minutes before taking it out of the oven because it melted a little too soon and got a bit crispy, rather than gooey.  But crispy was pretty darn good, too.  I'll no doubt be making this one again and again and again.

We had company over on Saturday and I was nervous about making this recipe since I had not tried it out first.  It was turned out really good. A good throw together meal that is a change of pace in tastes.  I also would suggest adding the cheese the last few minutes, because it did burn off a bit.  I also think a past reviewer had a good idea about using real bacon strips, bacon bits just get lost on top of the chicken.

text:
This dish is tasty and my family likes it, and I have made it several times but to me it is very salty  (Salty bacon bits, salty cheese, salty dressing, salty teriyaki sauce) and very greasy.  Just too much saltiness.  I found it is much better with less of everything and a buttermilk ranch and the prepackaged teriyaki marinated "Foster Farms" chicken.  Their teriyaki sauce is more sweet than salty.  The Kikoman teriyaki sauce is just kind of too much salt, better to try a sweeter brand or a low sodium version.  Otherwise this dish really is a heart attack waiting to happen.

It is good, just not really great because of the salty fatty nature of it.

text:
Following advice of other reviewers, we made the following modifications: 1. used 1/4 cup teriyaki sauce to reduce saltiness, 2. used low-fat/lite Ranch dressing, 3. used regular bacon (no bacon bits at our neighborhood grocery store).  Also, we cut the chicken into small pieces, and garnished with extra scallions.  My hubby served it over rice and with string beans.  This was a real winner!  We'll make it again...

text:
This chicken is delicious!!  My whole family loved it - even the picky kids.  I used the reduced sodium teriyaki as others suggested, but reduced the amount by about half  I also used fresh bacon, cooked and crumbled.  Save a bit of the cheese to sprinkle over the bacon and onions - it will keep them from drying out.  I served with rice and scooped some of the pan drippings over the rice.  Yum!  Can't imagine anyone giving this one less than 5 stars.

city:

country:
None
text:
The chicken looked fantastic with the green onion and red bacon. I served it to my in-laws and they raved about it! One thing that bothered me a bit was that there was a lot of not-so-nice-looking liquid in my dish at the end of baking and most of the bacon was floating in it. I used real bacon by microwaving 5 slices on a papertowel lined plate for 4 minutes. To save time, I did this earlier in the day. Then I crumbled it and and stored it with the sliced green onions in the fridge. When it was time to make the chicken, I was able to assemble them quickly. Overall, a great dish for company. Thanks for sharing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  This is a wonderful recipe.  I took a few suggestions from past reviewers and it turned out great.  Here is what I did,  I marinated the chicken overnight in teriyaki sauce.  Then, I browned the chicken in a pan with oil.  After removing the chicken, I sautéed mushrooms, green onions, and bacon in the pan juices.  I baked the chicken alone for about 25 minutes.  Then added the teriyaki, ranch, mushrooms, green onions, bacon, and cheese.  In 10 minutes it was ready.  This was so yummy.  We loved it!  I can't wait to make it for company.  Thanks.

text:
This is an interesting combination of flavors and we enjoyed it quite well. I wasn't sure how all the varied flavors would work together, so I went a little easy on everything so as not to waste a bunch of ingredients in case it wasn't good! But I was pleasantly surprised and will be making this again.  I did find it a slight bit salty, so next time I will probably use minimal teriyaki sauce and more of the ranch dressing.  The bacon (I used real crumbled bacon vs. the bacon bits) and green onion really added a nice twist.  A keeper....thanks!

Delicious recipe.  Even my picky three year old loved it!  Next time, I may reduce the 
teriyaki sauce (it turned out a bit salty) and the ranch dressing.  (they were both overflowing
on the chicken)  Also, the sauce that didn't flowed off the chicken was burning, so I'll either 
use a smaller pan or cover the nonchicken areas with foil.

I know this recipe has been reviewed hundreds of times but I wanted to add my praise.  My husband doesn't like to eat chicken, he gets bored with it but he ate seconds of this dish.  I make this to use up some of the cheaper brands of ranch dressing that we have on hand.  I used real bacon instead of the bacon bits and browned the chicken in the bacon grease (super healthy) and this has turned out wonderfully each time.  I think I'll make it again tonight!

text:
This is a very different and fun recipe.  The taste is quite unique.  I agree that it tastes a bit too salty (not too bad though) -- next time I will use low-sodium Teriyaki sauce and perhaps add a little bit of water to the sauce.  I definately recommend this recipe.  Serve with rice and spoon the extra sauce over the rice.  Steamed broccoli is a good light vegetable to serve with this.  I also used low-fat Ranch dressing and low-fat Hormel Bacon-Bits to make an easy and low-fat meal.  Very easy to make as well.  Thank you for sharing.

text:
This is a definite keeper and will do well for a company dinner. I marinated the chicken in the Teriyaki basting sauce for 2 hours and added the ranch dressing to the remaining marinade prior to spreading on the chicken breasts.  I used regular bacon that I had cooked previously.  I covered the casserole dish with foil and baked 35-40 minutes due to the size of the chicken breasts.  The chicken was very flavorful and moist.  I served with mixed vegetables and mashed potatoes.  The sauce was great on the potatoes.  Thanks VICKI.

text:
I've made this dish several times now & my family likes it.  I don't change anything when making a recipe for the first time.  However, after reading the reviews I decided to divide the dish (1st time) when I made it. One dish was exactly as it calls, and the other with a slight "tweek".  The "tweeked" dish won my family over. I only did a few simple things different:  1) used a low sodium teriyaki, 2) mixed teriyaki with ranch & tossed chicken in it,  3) used real bacon, 4) covered with foil. when baking.

text:
This was so easy and delicious! Definitely making this again. Instead of bacon bits, I cooked up bacon and then cut it up and garnished the top. While the chicken was cooking, I used some of the bacon grease to cook some vegetables like bell pepper, onion, garlic, and mushrooms with no seasonings because of the bacon juices. After the chicken was done cooking I served the chicken and vegetables over linguine noodles.

I was scared to try this recipe because the combination of ingredients did not sound appealing, but finally gave it a shot because of the good reviews. We all loved this dish! The only things I did differently was use chicken tenderloins, marinated the chicken for 30 minutes in the teriyaki sauce and baked in the oven for less time since using tenderloins. This was a great easy recipe! Surprising how good it was.

text:
I've made this several times in the last few months and it's a favorite. I can't eat onions, so I substituted frozen baby spinach. Don't skimp on t he teriyaki or ranch, it makes an AWESOME sauce! I didn't use fake bacon bits: I always cook bacon while the chicken is cooking, but in the microwave.  For the cheese topping, I use a Colby jack/Monterey jack combo, finely shredded and LOTS of it! It's easy and delicious!

text:
Like other reviews, thought it an odd combo but my family loved it.  I did n't find it overly salty (soy is salty inherently). i used kikkoman teriyaki baste and glaze as it has a far lower sodium content.  After I browned the Chix, i sauteed 2 green onions, 1/2 leek and portabello mushrooms.  Then followed directions, baking 20 min and then adding cheese for final time.    I served it over angel hair pasta with a caesar salad.  It would be nice over rice or mashed potatoes as well as there is plenty of sauce.  My husband said it's a keeper!

I was in charge of dinner for a hundred so I searched for a recipe and tried this one at home first. I was a little apprehensive when I saw the ranch dressing as an ingredient, but it was delicious and I received several compliments on it. I halved the larger chicken breast halves and brined the chicken in salt water for several hours the day before cooking. I must say I didn't measure anything but just poured (or sprinkled) it on.  I highly recommend this recipe!

text:
This was very good, but not great.  I had all of the ingredients on hand. I used fresh bacon  to cook, drain and crumble, in place of the pre packaged bacon bits. Based on other reviews, I did not sear the chicken first, I simply blended the ranch and Teryaki basting sauce and dipped the pieces of chicken in the mixture before placing them in the baking dish. There was sauce left over, but I decided not to pour it on top, because too many reviewers said this recipe was very salty and rich. I'm glad I made that decision. Again, based on other reviews I decided to wait until the last 10 minutes to add the  cheese, bacon and scallions. Everyone enjoyed dinner, it just wasn't as wonderful as I expected.

text:
I tried this recipe yesterday and was so surprised at the wonderful flavor!  I have a great Calphon pan that goes from the stovetop to the oven.  I made my own bacon bits(nueske's applewood smoked) and didn't have green onions but chopped an onion and sautéed it with the bacon drippings and chicken.  I had some dried chives for added color.  I always make my own Ranch dressing and teriyaki sauce so the homemade from scratch didn't hurt either.  I added long chinese noodles to the pan the last 10 minutes and covered the pan.  I will make this recipe at a next family gathering.

text:
Oh so good!  I was making this for a 35th anniversary dinner serving around 15 people and because of some reviews was worried about the dish being too salty.  Instead of the teriyaki (which did strike me as a little strange) just to be safe, I substituted barbeque sauce.  For everything else, I stuck to the recipe and it turned out awesome!!  I served it with a prepackaged Asian salad kit from the produce section, and I sliced potatoes and used a heart shaped cookie cutter to punch out the potatoes for roasting.  Everything was a smashing success, thanks for sharing!

text:
This was pretty good, but I actually thought it was bland. I thought baking the chicken in the sauce would give it great flavor, but unless if it was drowned in the sauce it just tasted like bland chicken. I must say though, the sauce is delicious! I was skeptical of the teryiaki/ranch combo but it really works. The ranch really mellows the teryiaki and makes it way more creamy. I may try to make this again by marinating for a few hours and maybe throwing it on  the grill as kabobs (minus the bacon and cheese, of course!).

text:
This was fantastic! I was skeptical about not putting any seasoning on the chicken as well as about the combination of teriyaki and ranch, but boy was I wrong! The flavor was out of this world. I prepared exactly as the recipe stated, with the exception of the fact that I sprayed the baking dish with Pam, which made for very easy clean-up. I also started out with full boneless, skinless chicken breasts, so after cooking for a couple of minutes in the skillet, I just sliced each one in half. I don't know if we just got lucky, but our chicken was not the least bit over-cooked or dry, and I even cooked in the skillet for slightly longer than the recipe called for. This recipe will definitely be on our regular dinner rotation!!

text:
Very delicious!  One note my partner suggested is 5 minutes before the dish is done, add more cheese on top of the chicken.  I didn't have green onions so I used regular white onions, about a half cup chopped.  I used ham (lunch meat) instead of bacon bits.  I added salt, pepper, onion spice & garlic spice (to taste).  Also, I added baby potatoes to the dish.  I poked holes in the potatoes with a fork and poured a little teriyaki sauce over the potatoes.  VERY YUMMY!

The second time I made it, I didn't brown the chicken and I used swiss cheese because I forgot to buy the cheddar.  My 17 year old has asked me to make it once a week! country:

text:
delicious!!! i loved this recipe, but as a warning to others it is on the salty side, but i prefer that so if you're sensitive to salty tasting foods, this might not be for you or look for low sodium ingredients. that having said, i brushed my chix with the basting sauce, then cooked about 5 strips of bacon and then cooked my chix in the drippings for about 10min. since i already put some of the basting sauce on the chix i only used about 1/8 c. more and mixed it together with about 1/4c ranch and then spooned the combined sauce over the chix and that was plenty for my 4 breasts. i added the remaining toppings and covered with foil and it was done in about 25 min. and also my sister made this recipe but in the crock pot like someone else suggested and she said next time she'll def make in the oven instead it didn't really look that great after being in the crock pot. i will definitely be making this again exactly how i did this time! the toppings make the chix! on bites where the topping had fallen off it was just okay so make sure you don't skimp on them!

I made roasted vegetables that went beautifully with this meal.

This chicken is awsome.  I cooked it for the first time for my church dinner and fed 60 people.  Everyone raved about it and asked for the recipe.  I was asked to make this a monthly item on the menu.  I did not saute the chicken because of the number I was feeding.  Will try this at home and saute as directed to compare.  Baked covered in a convection oven for about 25 minutes on low fan.  Chicken was moist and the sauce was great over the wild rice.  Definately a keeper.  Thanks Vicki!

text:
Okay... so I finally tried this out after seeing it for years on this site!!  I too was initially worried about the terryaki and ranch dressing combo.  I am happy to report.. it works well together.  Changes were.. omitted bacon bits, marinaded the cutlets in terryaki marinade for 1/2 hour.  And finally.. sauted some sliced mushrooms in the pan and placed on top of chicken.  I made extra sauce so that we had plenty for the egg noodles that I served with it.

text:
The best chicken I have ever had by FAR! I made a few substitutes due to the fact that I was missing a few ingredients. I used 0 Calorie Ranch, Monterey Jack cheese, and no bacon! But I followed the directions and the end result was wonderful. I was afraid the ranch and/or glaze would be over powering but it wasn't! I noticed a few bad reviews on this about it being too salty and/or creamy. I think the key to this recipe is to really know yourself and your taste-buds and make the proper adjustments. I made it a point not to over-do the glaze or ranch. It came out amazing and the whole family LOVED it! I am making this for my birthday dinner next month and am really excited to see peoples reactions!  Also, the "Beautiful Salad" by WENDYINTEXAS compliments this wonderfully!

text:
I have to say, I hope I did something wrong. I was surprised that I didn't think this was amazing based on the ratings. My boyfriend and I ate this 4 hours ago, and I still feel a bit ill. It's way too salty and rich.  Here's what I did: I marinated the chicken for about 20 minutes in the teriyaki, browned it, put ranch on it, baked it for 20 minutes, added the cheese and bacon bits (that were real bacon crumbles), and baked it for 10 more minutes. I didn't have green onions. That would have changed the flavor. I will NOT say that this was horrible. It just wasn't a 5-star meal to me. Maybe because my boyfriend and I have been eating more lightly? I don't know...
