text:
I took someones review and decided to try it in the crock pot. I took skinless bonless breast and did eggwash and breadcrumbs and browed them for about 5 mins then put the in the slow cooker with 1c teriyaki and 1/2 c of ranch and left it on low for about 5 hrs. the i put the cheese and bacon on top and baked for about 8 mins...it was HORRIBLE...it was WAY to salty and nobody took more than one bite...if you going to make this do not put it in the slow cooker!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very Very good!  My 8 year old fell in love!  I seasoned the chicken with a little garlic powder, dehydrated onion and pepper as I browned it in a little of the bacon grease...fried bacon and crumbled it instead of using jarred bacon bits.  Covered with foil and removed foil during last 5 min in oven.  When I took chicken out of oven, topped chicked with 1/3 cup reserved cheddar cheese and it melted beautifully. Served with bow tie pasta tossed in a little butter, salt & pepper and topped pasta with the sauce and served with some steamed broccli.  Extremely easy and sooooo delicious.  WIll definately make again soon!

I've already made this twice, and some friends of mine fell in love with it when I shared the recipe with them. Thanks!

text:
After the first bite my husband looked at me and said "This is the best thing you've ever made!" I did a couple things different...I mariniated the chicken in teriyaki for about an hour. Then I cooked the bacon and used the bacon grease to sautee the chicken. Although I may do this differently next time because the teriyaki burned a little bit. I sprinkled some garlic salt on the chicken before covering it with the ranch. I also waited until the last 10 minutes to add the cheese, bacon, and green onions.   It turned out really good and I will definitely be making this one again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was really skeptical about mixing the teriyaki sauce with the ranch sauce but once again, Allrecipes did not fail me! Based on the reviews, I just had to try this recipe and it was DELICIOUS! I didn't fry the chicken first, just threw it in the over. The chicken was moist and VERY savory! I don't recommend adding any additional salt or seasonings because the mixture of sauces along with the bacon (I used bacos real bacon bits) made it pretty salty.  I also think that mixing the ranch and the teriyaki was a good idea. All in all, a fabulous recipe. I'll be making again very soon! Perfect for company - something a little different to serve. The only thing I think I'd change is the name. :-) I think I'll dub this, "loaded baked potato chicken".

text:
This is how I made it: Mix the teriyaki and ranch, add chicken and marinate for a few hours.  Meanwhile, cook bacon strips.  Take chicken from marinade and grill over charcoal.  When just done, top each piece with two strips of bacon and slice of cheese. We all liked this recipe, and it is fast and has a very "restaurant" feel to it.  But even with marinating there wasn't a LOT of flavor, and I imagine the grilling added to it rather than subtracted. I hope I remember to make it again. :-)

text:
I thought this turned out really well. ((My husband and oldest daughter didn't care too much for it though.)) I marinated the chicken in the teriyaki while I fried some real bacon. Using a bit of the grease I lightly browned the chicken. Added to the dish and topped with the ranch and green onions. They baked for about 20 minutes and then I added a bunch of cheese and the crumbled bacon. I baked it another 15 minutes and they were ready. I thought the flavors were great and the chicken was very juicy. But the other two said is was just OK. Well, I am the cook and I will make it again!!

text:
I did like this recipe, but it wasn't the ground-breaking meal that I was expecting based on reviews. That said, this was a VERY easy recipe and definitely good enough to whip up on a weeknight with ingredients I generally have on hand. I really liked that I didn't have to marinate the meat because I rarely plan that far ahead. I took someone else's suggested to season and dredge the chicken before sauteeing. But with the salty teriyaki sauce, I wish I wouldn't have salted the chicken beforehand. Next time, I think I'll be a little more generous with the ranch and cheese.

text:
My family absolutely loves this recipe! It's requested all the time, and the only thing I do differently is cook and crumble fresh bacon on top. I have used both red and green onions, and find both to be delicious, but I try to use green when I can. Also, never really felt the need for parsley, so I just skip it....Oh, and I never bother to brown the chicken first. It comes out tender and juicy every time.. just up the cooking time to 40 minutes or so

text:
I was really disappointed with the taste of the sauce. I wound up having to buy a store-brand teriyaki sauce with pinapple, so I wonder if that's what the problem was. I first marinated the chicken in the teriyaki sauce and after pan frying the chicken, I had mixed the teriyaki sauce and ranch dressing before spooning it on the chicken. I then put the cheddar cheese, spring onions and cheese on about 10 minutes before the meal was done. I served it with Texas toast and corn. The chicken was very moist but the Texas toast and corn was the best part. I'm rating it as a 3 for how easy it was. Sorry!  I'm updating this about 12 hours later... I must have been sick or something last night. No doubt! I just warmed up the left overs... wow!!! I like this a LOT more than I did last night. Myself, though, I would prefer something a little extra... possibly more salt or more tanginess, but again it could be because of the teriyaki sauce I had used. I'm really enjoying my dinner tonight!

text:
Delicious but I too had a problem with it being too salty - even my salt addicted husband agreed.  Luckily I tasted the sauce before baking and modified it by adding water, sugar, and more ranch.  The problem was the teriyaki sauce I bought at the store not the recipe itself.    In short, buy a THICK LOW SODIUM teriyaki sauce or make your own teriyaki sauce (what I usually do & should have done) and it will turn out perfect :)  Oh, and add the cheese and real bacon crumbles at the end so they don't burn :)

text:
Huge hit!  Everyone loved this dish - including my picky 13 year old.  I would highly recommend cooking real bacon to crumble over the top rather than using bacon bits.  I used Ken's Teriyaki and it was just the right amount.  Oddly, no one could tell there was teriyaki or ranch dressing on the chicken - which I think was a good thing!  The flavors combined to give this dish a unique and delicious taste.  One thing I might do differently next time is wait to put the cheese on since I had the same issue as other reviewers with the melting cheese sliding off the chicken.

userID:
2307296
Display Name:
Dawn Stone
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
30
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed another reviewer's suggestion and made sure to use a Teriyaki glaze, which was a good call since it was thicker. I think even a barbecue sauce would work well here. I forgot to brown the chicken and just put it in a 9 X 13 pan and then poured the Teriyaki sauce on top and rubbed it in. I cooked it for 15 mins at 350, then I flipped the breasts, drained a bit of the juice, poured on some Ranch dressing and the bacon bits and cooked it another 15 mins. Then I turned the oven off and sprinkled some shredded cheddar cheese all over it and kept it in the oven til the cheese had melted. I was very good! I think I would prefer it with real bacon next time and maybe some sliced mushrooms under the cheese. Then it will taste a lot like a chicken dish that I get at Outback Steakhouse. Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
2555803
Display Name:
Alaska Mom
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7212261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  We butterflied the chicken, pounded it, coated it with egg and then seasoned with Italian breadcrumbs it before browning.  This yielded quite a bit of chicken.  We then ended up with two layers in the 9x13 pan.  Each layer had the teriyaki basting sauce, the ranch dressing (used fat free) and the cheese.  We added the bacon bits and the green onion on top and then covered the pan with aluminum foil.  Since we had butterflied the chicken and then pounded it, the oven cooking time was 15 minutes.  The chicken was nice and tender.  The presentation was great!  The only drawback were the onions.  They were a bit too strong.
Review:

4

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
i didnt find my chicken to be salty at all, but made sure to always add pepper. heres what i did:

i cooked my own bacon which i added some peppercorns to, 2 cloves minced garlic in some evoo. while that was cooking, i cut slits in the chicken and added a teriyaki marinade for about 15 minutes. i then cooked the chicken in the bacon grease until done on both sides and place in my baking dish. i added some fresh ground pepper on top, and then just drizzled the chicken with ranch. i didnt follow any of the marinade measurements. i added the cheese and bacon the last 10 minutes and fresh parsley on top when it came out of the oven. i served with broccoli, garlic mashed potatoes and hawaiian sweet rolls. im not sure i would make this dish for children, i dont think they would like the tanginess of the flavors mixed.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite tasty.  Also, there is something kind of addicting about the flavor of ranch and teriyaki.  Yes, it is very salty, so to those who are salt intolerant, this is not for you.  I will probably experiment with different sauces until I find one to my liking.  I used Soy Vey teriyaki and homemade ranch(from the dry pkg).  I think barbecue and ranch would be awesome together.  I might try that next.  Two things I did that made everything easier was go ahead and mix both sauces together and pour over browned chicken and I premixed my shredded cheese, chopped green onions, and bacon pieces in a ziploc baggie and 25 minutes into the cooking time, topped chicken with it and cooked for 10 more minutes.  All in all, we all thought it was pretty tasty.

text:
This was a great recipe.  My husband loved it.  It was a tad salty but that was probably the choice of sauce and ranch dressing I used.  I also used real bacon pieces instead of bacon bits.  I tried using the pre-cooked bacon since I hate to cook bacon and I was very pleased with its taste so I recommend that verses bacon bits.  Like others suggested I added the cheese the last 10 min. Will definitely make again.  Thanks!  Update:  I cook the chicken in the oven in the same skillet I brown it in and I also added thin sliced potatoes around the edges lightly oiled and it turned out great!  Just add a side veggie and your done.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out really well. As mentioned by another reviewer, I gave the chicken an egg wash and flour breading before browning it in the skillet. This added a nice crispy texture to the finished dish. And instead of basting the chicken with the teriyaki, I mixed it with the ranch dressing and spooned it on.  As for the cheese mixture, I omitted the onion (picky husband) and waited until the final 10 minutes to add the topping.  It was bubbly, crispy, gooey, and perfect! I even made a little pan gravy with the drippings from the casserole dish. I will surely make this again!

text:
My family loved this, even my picky eater! I did it a little bit differently and it still came out great. I put the raw chicken in the crock pot, added the ranch dressing and then used chipotle sauce instead of teriyaki. I cooked bacon and added that, too. I didn't add any cheese in the crock pot. I just let my kids add it if they wanted it. Delish! Drew rave reviews from all who ate it, and I will definitely make it again.

Made the teriyaki sauce and ranch dressing from scratch, so I'm all proud of myself, lol. Got rave reviews. I had to use pork steaks (my mom doesn't eat chicken) but it tasted really good, surely as good as with chicken. Marinated the meat the day before (garlic, black pepper, olive oil) and didn't brown it before baking it. Didn't add the bacon bits and cheese, but tossed some mushrooms along with the ranch dressing. Thanx ;)

text:
Yummy!  5 Stars for easy to make, quick to the table (I don't think it took a whole hour like the directions say), and delicious - even for my picky kids! YUM! To make it easy: I used Oscar Meyer Real Bacon Bits - the ones like beef jerky in the condiment aisle, and I didn't have teriyaki sauce, so I simmered 1 c. soy sauce with 3/4 c. water and 3/4 c. sugar with a clove of chopped garlic & 3 green onions chopped, it tasted just like the jarred versions of teriyaki sauce. I added the cheese on the last 5 minutes. Delish!!! Thank you, Wanda, for the wonderful chicken recipe!!!

text:
I made this for a pot luck dinner and everyone requested the recipe.  I used chicken tenders and only browned them on one side.  The dish is a little bit greasy so the second time I made it, I used low fat cheddar and a little less bacon bits (I used real bacon).  You could probably use a low fat ranch dressing too with good results.

text:
The flavor of this was excellent.  I used Just 2 Good low fat ranch dressing and low fat cheddar cheese.  The only complaint my husband had was that all the topping slid off and was gone before he was done with the chicken breast.  The taste was so good he wanted it in every bite.  I think next time I may cut the chicken breasts into big chunks and then put all the toppings on to get better coverage.  You would have to adjust cooking time but I am going to give it a try.

text:
OMG!  This was astoundingly good!  My 6 yr. old raved!  My 12 yr. old devoured the stuff!  My husband was near estacy!  (Me, too!)  I can't wait to make it again!  I used low sodium teriyaki, and low fat Ranch, and low fat Cheddar.  Wonderful, and so easy!
NOTE - Don't use fat free ranch dressing!  I did the 2nd time I prepared this, and it just wasn't anywhere near as good.  It changed the texture, flavor and appearance.  This dish is soooo good as written!  It's worth using regular Ranch Dressing!

text:
I made this tonight after reading all of the reviews.  My picky husband and my VERY picky 6 yr old LOVED IT.  We are adding it to our rotation!  I did make a couple of changes to mine that were suggested.  I cooked real bacon, and fried the chicken in the bacon dippings instead of oil.  For the teriyaki sauce, I found the KC Masterpiece Honey Teriyaki marinade worked awesome (1/4 cup).  It has about 1/2 the sodium as the kikkoman brand.  I've passed this recipe to 2 neighbors already!!!

text:
Yummy, different, cheap, and easy - 4 things I love in a recipe! After reading the reviews here, I added the cheese and bacon (I snipped up about 4 slices of pre-cooked bacon - I'd like to hug whoever invented that stuff!) during the last 15 minutes of cooking and it turned out great. I think next time I'll try it without the cheese to cut down on the fat, and because the flavors of the teriyaki/ranch sauce are flavorful enough without it. (And I could live on cheese so for me that's saying a lot!) A great recipe!

text:
Wow!  I just looked back in my "recipe box" to see approx. how long my DH and I have loved this recipe *drum roll*...since at least 2002.  It is by far our favorite chix recipe.  In fact, despite it only being 5a.m. my taste buds are warming up!  LOL :)  At any rate, the ONLY thing I do differently is to marinate the breasts in teriyaki, or, if don't have teriyaki on hand, low sodium soy with a splash of oil and a "blop" of honey.  Heavenly!  Thanks again Vicki!!!  (Oh, and btw, I considered going back and reading my previous review - but 696 seemed too daunting!!)

text:
We really like the combination of flavors in this dish, although I use real bacon.  I've made it twice: once with boneless breasts, and once with boneless thighs.  The thighs are MUCH better--really tender and juicy.  The breasts were okay, but kind of dry.  Yes, thighs have more fat, but if you are making this dish, you're obviously not worried about fat content!

text:
My family doesn't care for teriyaki flavoring so I substituted salsa. It was awesome! I have also tried ranch dip mix (which is thicker) instead of the ranch dressing. Everything stuck to the chicken alot better. I also found stabbing the breasts with a knife and then browning them on the grill is alot faster and cleaner than stove top browning. It is now a family favorite.

country:
None
text:
Well, I must say, I was surprised at how good this recipe really was.  Reading the ingredient list I had visions of chicken drowning in coagulated clumps of ranch dressing, but I had to try it anyway due to its extreme popularity.  Once you spread out the ingredients between 6 chicken breasts, it's not too gloppy, and once the teriyaki and ranch blended and baked together, the resulting sauce tasted like neither one.  We used real bacon, chopped up and fried crisply, instead of the fake-un bits, and we sauteed some mushrooms in some of the bacon fat and added those too.  Good comfort food.  Mmmmm.

Display Name:
JDRICKER

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Can use bone-in chicken breast halves.  Use size pan according to how many breast using.  After browning (you do not have to brown if in a hurry), brush breast with teriyaki - I use the rule of -- 1 Tblsp. dressing per breast (I used a jalapeno ranch) - one green onion per breast - cheese over top of breast.  I omitted the bacon.  Last 10-15 minutes, I added quartered tomatoes and partially cooked asparagus.  Great recipe and all my family cooks are now using it.

It's too greasy, you cannot taste the ranch dressing, ...I read that it was too salty for a lot of people so I used low-sodium teriyaki,and increased the amount of ranch dresssing but,I guess I sould have used a lot more of the ranch dressing because tit came out a bit dry.) The only two things that we could  taste were the cheddar cheese and the bacon.....Sorry! I would  NOT recommend this one
